title: Git and GitHub
text: At R For The Rest Of Us, we collaborate on projects using Git and GitHub. Git is the gold standard for version control, and using it in conjunction with GitHub provides a neat way of exploring the more advanced Git features within a friendly interface. This section covers the basics of the Git etiquette we adopt, as well as a few how-tos and worked examples.

title: Git and GitHub
section: How we organise (and talk about) the basics
text:
How we organise (and talk about) the basics

Each project has its own unique repository
The central repository for each project lives on GitHub; this is also referred to as origin
Everyone working on that project is invited to the GitHub repo, and we then clone the repo to our own computers (this gives us what we call local repos)

The rest of this section assumes a basic understanding of how Git works. The main thing to note for new users is that, unlike something like Dropbox, changes only make it to the central repo (and from there to others), if Git is explicitly told about them via add, commit and push commands.

Setting up a new repo
The easiest way to create a new repo is to do it on GitHub. Make sure to give it a name that clearly identifies the project!
 Then follow the instructions that come up once you‚Äôve clicked on Create Repository. Pick the option that best corresponds to the stage you have reached. If you have already used git init to make your local folder into a Git repo, pick the second option. If not, pick the first.



screenshot of init instructions


When creating a new repo, we want to add three files: README.md (which is added automatically in the first option), .gitignore and .gitattributes. The default branch of a new repo should be called main. This is GitHub‚Äôs new default, so should happen automatically.

README.md
This file should contain information about the purpose of the repo, and any information useful to other team members interacting with it. We sometimes make our repos available to clients towards the end of projects, so keep the contents of the README accessible to non-R specialists.


.gitignore
The best way to do this is by using {usethis} within R. Navigate to your repo, and type:

usethis::git_vaccinate()

This will add a .gitignore file that excludes files with the following extensions from being tracked by Git.
.Rproj.user
.Rhistory
.Rdata
.httr-oauth
.DS_Store


.gitattributes
This file allows us to work across different Operating Systems, which have different behaviours for handling line endings. Create a text file and rename it to .gitattributes (note, not gitattributes.txt) and copy the following content into it:
# Let Git's auto-detection algorithm infer if a file is text. If it is,
# enforce LF line endings regardless of OS or git configurations.
* text=auto eol=lf

# Isolate binary files in case the auto-detection algorithm fails and
# marks them as text files (which could break them).
*.{png,jpg,jpeg,gif,webp,woff,woff2} binary




Cloning an existing repo
To clone a repo from GitHub, it either needs to be public, or you need to have been invited to the repo. We invite all team members to the sandbox repo we created, and use it as a way of exploring different Git tricks.
To clone the repo, go to its GitHub page and click on Code, copy the text provided by GitHub by clicking on the copy icon.



screenshot showing how to copy the url of the repo we want to clone


Next, create a new folder called sandbox somewhere on your computer. Navigate to that folder in your terminal, and type git clone then paste in the text you‚Äôve just copied, type space then . and hit Enter. That full stop means ‚Äúclone the folder into the directory where I am currently‚Äù. If you miss that out, you‚Äôll end up with this git folder called sandbox inside your sandbox folder which will make things very confusing. Your command should look like this:
git clone https://github.com/rfortherestofus/sandbox.git .
This will create a local copy of the repo on your computer.
Depending on how your computer is set up, you may see a folder called .git. This is a hidden folder. Do not edit its contents!

title: Git and GitHub
text:
Git etiquette

Commit messages
There is an art to writing good commit messages.



Commit messages comic illustrating how not to do it! From xkcd.com


Some organisations have very strict guidelines on that. Here, we just try to follow the following rules:

Commit often and frequently; this allow you to easily backtrack to the point where your code was doing what it should be.
Write clear commit messages. Things like ‚ÄúI fixed it!‚Äù are not all that helpful when trying to find a commit that addressed a specific problem!
If the change you‚Äôre making is linked to an issue on GitHub (we‚Äôll come to issues later), include the number of the issue in the commit message (e.g.¬†‚ÄúAdded section on commit messages - #4‚Äù). GitHub picks this up and adds a message into the issue, which allows us to easily keep track of progress.




Screenshot of GitHub issue #4 featuring the commit above




Using branches
We encourage the use of branches when collaborating on projects. These can be daunting to new Git users, but once we get the hang of them, there‚Äôs no looking back!

What are branches?
We mentioned the default branch, main earlier. Think of this as the ‚Äústable universe‚Äù as far as the project is concerned. It contains up-to-date code that others can reliably use. A branch is essentially an ‚Äúalternate universe‚Äù for the project, where we can experiment, make changes, test new things, all without disrupting the ‚Äústable universe‚Äù that others rely on.
Some organisations only ever allow changes to be made via a branch. There‚Äôs lot of wisdom in that, but sometimes it can become cumbersome. Here are some use cases where you could consider working in the main branch:

you are the only person working on the project
you are adding something to the project that doesn‚Äôt interact at all with the code others are writing

But even in those cases, you could consider using a new branch to be on the safe side. If in doubt, check with David.


Creating a new branch
Creating a new branch is trivial. As with commit messages, we want to make sure the name of the branch gives a clear indication of its purpose. Say a client wants to add a new timeline to their report. The report is otherwise working as it should be. To work in a branch, and thereby allow them to keep using the report as is while you figure this out, you‚Äôll want to

make sure you‚Äôre branching off an up-to-date main: git pull
create a new branch with a clear name: git checkout -b adding-timeline-feature

You can also do this in RStudio or in GitHub Desktop.
Now the files that you see are ones that belong to your alternate universe called ‚Äúadding timeline feature‚Äù. Everything will look the same, but changes you add and commit here won‚Äôt affect anything in main; if it all goes horribly wrong, you can delete this branch and know all is still well in the ‚Äústable universe‚Äù. You can then switch between universes as follows:

Commit (or stash) everything you‚Äôve done within your branch
Go back to the ‚Äústable universe‚Äù: git checkout main, probably followed by git pull to see what‚Äôs happened there in your absence. The modifications you‚Äôve made within adding-timeline-feature will no longer be visible to you.
Go back to your own alternate universe: git checkout adding-timeline-feature, and your modifications are back!

While you‚Äôre working on your feature, you can keep your branch backed up on GitHub, safe in the knowledge that it doesn‚Äôt affect anything in main. The first time you push, you need to ‚Äúset the upstream‚Äù.
git push -u origin adding-timeline-feature
Every time after that, you can just use git push. Pushing your branch to origin allows others to view your branch (useful if you want to get feedback along the process), and ensures that if something bad happens to your computer, your work is stored somewhere else. Give it a go in our sandbox repo.
Create a new branch, with a name of your choosing, and add a quote to quotes/client-quotes.txt. Add, commit and push (remember to set the upstream branch!). Then checkout main again, and open the client-quotes.txt file. The quote you‚Äôve added should no longer be there. Switch back to your branch, and it will reappear. The GitHub page for this repo should also now include your branch in the list of branches.


Creating a pull request
Pull request are the way we merge the work you‚Äôve done in a branch back into our ‚Äústable universe‚Äù while allowing someone else to review the changes in the process.
TODO: example create a pull request for the added quote TODO: best for the branch author / person who made the most recent contribution to it to initiate the pull request TODO: get up to speed with main first.


Reviewing a pull request
TODO: We haven‚Äôt really done this, but it might be worth thinking about if projects get bigger - you can set things so that a merge into main needs to be approved by someone other than the person creating the pull request; a useful way to keep things safe, but we need to all be happy with pull requests first


Merging etiquette and branch hygiene
At this point comes a policy decision, which can be influenced by workload: who completes the approved merge? It could be the person who did the work, or the person who approved the merge. If there happen to be conflicts (see below), this can be non trivial. GitHub will tell you if there will be a conflict, in which case we can discuss who is best placed to resolve it.
And a second policy decision, which can be influenced by how we want to use the branches: should a branch be deleted once it has been merged in? The advantage of deleting branches as part of the merge is that this avoids needing to tidy them up at a later stage. You might have a feature you‚Äôre working on where a quick bug fix was needed, but you‚Äôd like to keep working on it to improve the code once the immediate need for the bug fix has passed. In that case, it might be best to keep the branch, but we‚Äôll need to make sure we keep it up to speed with the ‚Äústable universe‚Äù by merging main into that branch before picking it up again.
To check the status of your branch(es) compared to others, click on the ‚Äúbranches‚Äù icon in the repo‚Äôs GitHub page. Here you can see by how many commits a branch is ahead and behind the default branch (typically main). A branch that is ‚Äúbehind‚Äù main by a large number of commits and hasn‚Äôt been updated for a while is probably a candidate for deletion, but if it wasn‚Äôt your branch, check with its author first!



Dealing with merge conflicts
The best way to deal with conflicts is to avoid causing them in the first place!

title: Production
text:
After the instructor provides raw videos, David edits them. Most lessons have the following structure:

Full screen on instructor as they introduce topic
Switch to instructor in corner with their screen as background
As the instructor talks about code, zoom in on it (pan back out when they‚Äôre done talking about the specific code)
Switch back to full-screen on instructor when they‚Äôre not talking about code at all
Do pans on other websites etc as appropriate
My Turn as appropriate
Your Turn as appropriate




Use a 0.2 second length Cross Blur transition
Detach audio and use audio smoothing
Make sure audio doesn‚Äôt have any transitions
You can take full-length screenshots with Firefox

Example walkthrough of me editing video: https://show.rfor.us/z1fUk4

text:
Captions
Captions are added using muse.ai or Descript. Captions for courses are then edited by hand to make sure they are accurate.

text: Putting Content on Website

title: Tools
text: This is an overview of tools we use. Details on how we use them are laid out in other pages in the handbook.

title: Tools
text:
Handbook
You‚Äôre reading the handbook made in Quarto. We use Quarto to create internal docs that show how R for the Rest of Us runs.

title: Tools
text:
Communication
Email happens through Gmail. We have access to the full Google Suite tools, but only use Docs, Sheets, etc periodically.
Twist is where we communicate internally.

title: Tools
text:
Task/Project Management
We use Todoist to lay out tasks to be done on projects. Generally speaking, we only lay out major milestones on Todoist projects (e.g.¬†finish all data viz on X project on July 23). Communication about specific tasks should happen in the comments section of those tasks.
Code-based projects have major milestones laid out in Todoist, but then use GitHub to discuss individual issues.

title: Tools
text:
Time Tracking
Time tracking happens in Toggl.

title: Tools
text:
Scheduling
We use SavvyCal to schedule meetings with clients.

title: Tools
text:
Financial
We use QuickBooks for accounting and invoicing.
Payroll happens through Gusto.

title: Tools
text:
Proposal and Contracts
Proposals and contracts are written and sent with PandaDoc.

title: Tools
text:
Design
We use Figma and Canva to make all design assets.

title: Tools
text:
Passwords
We manage passwords with 1Password.

title: Tools
text:
Website
The website runs on WordPress and is hosted by Kinsta. There are various paid plugins that help do specific things on the website. See Website.
Website analytics are provided by Fathom.

title: Tools
text:
Video Creation
When providing quick feedback videos, we use CloudApp or CleanShot.
To record videos for courses, we use either Screenflow, OBS Studio, Streamlabs (depending on instructor operating system + preferences).
Video editing happens in Screenflow.
Captions for videos are made using Descript or muse.ai.

title: Tools
text:
Video Hosting
Course videos, teaching videos, etc are hosted on muse.ai and embedded on the website.
There is an R for the Rest of Us YouTube channel that I‚Äôve only periodically used.

title: Tools
text:
Social Media
We use two tools to schedule social media content:

Buffer is where we set up a queue of regular R content created by others to go out on Twitter. We also post our own content using Buffer, often piped through a Zapier automation from Airtable.
If we need to schedule Twitter threads, we use Typefully.

title: Tools
text:
Automation
We use Zapier to automate various processes (e.g.¬†when a user completes a course, Zapier sends that data to ConvertKit).

title: Curriculum
text:
You‚Äôll start out by creating an outline of your course. This will be done in the GitHub repo that David creates for your course.
Please just create an outline.Rmd file for this. Use the following format:
Section Name (H1)
Lesson Title (H2)
Overview of lesson
My Turn (H3)
Overview of what you‚Äôll demonstrate
Your Turn (H3)
Exercise for student
Solutions Code (H3)
Code used for solution to Your Turn
Learn More (H3)
Text with additional info, resources, etc on topic of lesson

title: Curriculum
text:
Sections
R for the Rest of Us courses are broken up into lessons and sections. Related lessons should be combined into sections. For example, my Fundamentals of R course has sections on RMarkdown, Data Wrangling and Analysis, and Data Visualization.

title: Curriculum
text:
Lessons
The number of lessons varies by course. However, as a general rule, core courses tend to be longer (between 30 and 40 lessons) while topics courses tend to be shorter (15 to 30 lessons).
Each lesson should cover one distinct topic. Each lesson within a section should be short and focus on a single topic. As you‚Äôre making your materials, if you think that a video demonstrating the concept will go beyond 10 minutes or so, consider breaking it into multiple lessons.
Each lesson has the following sections:

Video overview
Your Turn exercise (some lessons don‚Äôt lend themselves to this and don‚Äôt have an exercise)
Code and video solutions (only if there is a Your Turn)
Learn More section with links to resources on that topic

Here‚Äôs what it looks like (you can see this lesson here).

I typically start a lesson with slides. I‚Äôll start with a slide that lays out the concept. I‚Äôll often have code on this slide.
I‚Äôll usually then flip over to RStudio to show myself typing out the code to demonstrate this concept in an exercises file. I call this the My Turn. Here‚Äôs a sample lesson.

title: Curriculum
text:
Materials
The materials for each courses lives in a GitHub repo on the R for the Rest of Us organization account. David will create this and add you to the repo.

Slides
Slides for R for the Rest of Us courses are made using the xaringan package.
There is a custom template to use to make slides in the R for the Rest of Us style. You can access this by installing the rfortherestofus package using the following code:



You can then add slides by going to File > New File > RMarkdown and selecting the R for the Rest of Us template.

Please create a slides directory where all of your slides will live.
You can create slides as follows:
Most lessons should have a My Turn and a Your Turn section. The slide for the My Turn section should have an orange background and the slide for the Your Turn section should have a dark background. To do this, add the class my-turn and the class inverse to your slides as follows:



Other Materials
Any other materials that you want people to access can live in the repo. Please organize however you see fit.

title: David‚Äôs Work
text:
As R for the Rest of Us has grown, my work away from doing all of the teaching and all of the consulting to being someone who facilitates others doing this work. In 2021, I make a conscious decision to try to achieve two goals:
To achieve the first goal, I did two things:
To achieve the second goal, I have worked with consultants on a range of projects.

title: David‚Äôs Work
text:
Core Responsibilities
David‚Äôs core responsibilities are below. To be clear, I do a LOT more than just these things. But these are the high-leverage things that I should focus my time and attention on.

Strategy
Think about the future direction of R for the Rest of Us
Ensure we have the team necessary to achieve goals


Marketing
Develop blog posts and other content
Maintain email automation system
Regularly share useful R content through social media


Consulting Business Development
Meet with potential clients about consulting projects
Develop proposals for clients


Consulting Project Management
Communicate with clients about project progress
Work with consultants to get projects done on time


Course Development
Reach out to potential instructors to gauge interest
Work with instructors to develop courses
Create courses on website
Marketing courses

title: Terms
text: Here are the legal and financial terms that I typically use when working with course instructors (this is the broad overview; you will receive a full contract with this all spelled out). I‚Äôm flexible and happy to work with you to come up with a solution that meets both of our needs.

title: Terms
text:
Compensation
I pay an advance to the course creator of $500, half on signing the contract to work together, and the other half when the course is released.
Revenue for the courses is split 60/40 (60% for R for the Rest of Us, 40% for the course creator). I pay any royalties owed to the course creator on a quarterly basis.

title: Terms
text:
Ownership
All videos are owned by R for the Rest of Us. All non-video materials will be made freely available on the R for the Rest of Us organization GitHub using a CC-BY-SA-4.0 License.

title: Terms
text:
Exclusivity
The instructor agrees not to create a course that covers the same topic on another online platform for at least 12 months from the release of this course.

title: Terms
text:
Agreement Expiration
These terms remain in effect for one year after the course is released. After that, David and the instructor will discuss any possible changes to the terms.

title: Website
text: R for the Rest of Us runs on a WordPress website hosted by Kinsta.

title: Website
text:
Theme
The site uses the BuddyBoss theme. Some of the most important pages (e.g.¬†Home, About, Consulting) are generated with custom templates that use Tailwind CSS. These are edited locally, the templates are pushed to this GitHub repo, and then the WP Pusher plugin adds them to the website.

title: Website
text:
Custom Post Types
I‚Äôve created several custom post types using the Pods plugin:

Clients hosts pages with content for specific clients
Presentations
Resources hosts resources for the resources page
Success Stories hosts pages that highlight successful projects we‚Äôve worked on
Thanks hosts various pages that say thanks to people (used mostly for when people click things in ConvertKit)

title: Website
text:
Plugins
The website uses many plugins. Here are some of the most important and less obvious ones.
AffiliateWP enables us to have affiliates who are paid for referring customers (not currently using this)
BuddyBoss Platform + BuddyBoss Platform Pro hosts groups and forums for cohort-based courses
ConvertKit allows me to do things like apply a tag to a customer whenever they purchase a course
FacetWP is what I use to create a searchable, filterable resources page
LearnDash is probably the most important plugin. It is what we use to manage all courses. BuddyBoss integrates with it, making the course pages even more attractive. The one thing to note with LearnDash is that we use WooCommerce for signup and just use LearnDash itself for the course stuff.

LearnDash Course Duplicator allows us to duplicate courses (e.g.¬†for new cohorts of R in 3 Months)

NinjaForms is what we use for all forms
Pods creates custom post types
SEOPress + SEOPress Pro is used for all SEO stuff
Uncanny Automator + Uncanny Automator Pro allow us to automate various things (e.g.¬†sending notifications on new comments to Twist)
WooCommerce is how we handle all ecommerce on the site. We also use add-on Woo plugins:

WooCommerce Price Based on Country allows us to set lower prices for those in lower GDP countries
WooCommerce Product Vendors allows us to track commissions for course instructors
WooCommerce Smart Coupons allows us to set up coupons for gift certificates
WooCommerce Stripe Gateway allows us to use Stripe to process credit cards (we also reluctantly use PayPal)
WooCommerce Zapier allows us to create coupons for users from using Zapier when they are in their pitch window (see Email Marketing)

WP Pusher syncs our child theme from this GitHub repo to the website

title: Welcome
text: Welcome! You are reading an in-progress version of the R for the Rest of Us handbook.

title: Welcome
text:
Mission
The goal of R for the Rest of Us is to help people use R to do good in the world.

title: Welcome
text:
Our Work
The business has two main arms: education and consulting.

Education
On the education side, we offer:

Self-paced and cohort-based courses
In-person public workshops
Custom training for organizations



Consulting
On the consulting side, we do a range of projects. Almost all of them involve some combination of:

Data visualization
Using R to improve workflows
Automating reporting (especially with parameterized reporting)

title: Welcome
text:
Roadmap
As a business that does both education and consulting work, the R for the Rest of Us roadmap is guided by internal and external factors. We do our best to be thoughtful about future directions we think are useful based on customer feedback while also leaving space to adjust based on new information.

title: Welcome
section: A Business with a Social Conscience
text:
A Business with a Social Conscience
R for the Rest of Us is not just a money-making enterprise. I also want it to be a business with a social conscience. We put this into practice by:

Highlighting important issues in the work we do (e.g.¬†the types of projects we work on)
Making it possible for people of various means to learn R (through parity purchasing power and scholarships)
Donating a portion of revenue to organizations working for social justice

title: Welcome
text:
People
R for the Rest of Us is headed by David Keyes. I‚Äôve outlined my role in David‚Äôs Responsibilities.
Current consultants include Charlie Hadley, Thomas Vroylandt, Cara Thompson, Crystal Lewis, and Joscelin Rocha-Hidalgo. Other consultants are brought in for individual projects.

title: Branding
text:
The best description of branding that I‚Äôve read is from Gumroad:
When I think about who typical customers are for education products, here‚Äôs the persona I have in mind:
With this persona in mind, I‚Äôve intentionally tried to make the R for the Rest of Us personality:
All of the marketing I do takes a laid-back, conversational approach. I start all emails, for example, with the phrase ‚ÄúHi friend‚Äù. Any time someone asks a question, I reassure them it‚Äôs a good question (people are afraid to ask ‚Äúdumb‚Äù questions when it comes to R). These are a couple ways I try to implement the brand.

title: Branding
text:
Logo, colors, typography
When most people think of branding, this is what they‚Äôre asking about. You can find the various logos, colors, and typography that I use on Canva.

title: Social Media
text:
Social media is the main marketing strategy to help people become aware of R for the Rest of Us. The main platform we use is Twitter, as that‚Äôs where most R users are. We also market through LinkedIn.
All social media is designed not so much to sell directly (though we do a bit of this), but to get people on the R for the Rest of Us email list (see Email Marketing). Once they are on that list, we attempt to educate them and convince them to buy products form us.

title: Social Media
text:
Twitter
Active R users are on Twitter. We try to reach them not so much to sell to them directly (though this does sometimes happen), but more to have them connect people looking to learn R (who currently users are likely to know) with R for the Rest of Us.

We find R content produced by others and tweet it out on weekdays at 6am using Buffer.
We share R for the Rest of Us content on Thursdays at 9am. I‚Äôve done this by using a Zapier integration that connects Airtable to Buffer.
We also regularly share promotional material (i.e.¬†links directly to a course) using Buffer or Typefully (if we want to schedule a thread). We don‚Äôt currently have a schedule for this, but probably should.

title: Social Media
text:
LinkedIn
In the first half of 2022, we set up content to go out to LinkedIn. We should continue to do this.

title: Recording
text: Once you‚Äôve developed the course curriculum, you‚Äôre ready to record. Here are some tips to help you do so successfully.

title: Recording
text:
Defaults
Please use defaults when you teach. This means having your RStudio set up to look like it would for a student. If you move your panels around, for example, please revert to the default when recording lessons.
Please also use default fonts while you are teaching. Pretty as they are, please don‚Äôt use fonts like Fira Code, as the differences in how they render the assignment operator, for example, can be confusing for newbies.

title: Recording
text:
Code Style
Please follow the tidyverse style guide as closely as possible. The most important thing is to have code that is easy to read for new learners. You‚Äôre welcome to use the styler package to format your code.

title: Recording
text:
Recording Videos
I record using Screenflow. If you‚Äôre on a Mac, you‚Äôll get a license for it. If not, we‚Äôll discuss options.

Recording Procedures
I‚Äôm generally not that fussy about making sure everything is super high quality, but please use an external camera and external mic to record. Please put your mic as close to you as possible, but make sure it doesn‚Äôt show up on camera. If you are interested in learning some tips about high-quality screencasting, this guide from Egghead is helpful.
My general experience is that it‚Äôs easier to record videos by just hitting record and going through your lesson as many times as you need to. I often make mistakes along the way, but that‚Äôs ok because we can edit them out after the fact. Just go back to right before you messed up and start again! You can, of course, record so you get a single high-quality take, but I find that hard to do and way too much pressure.


Sharing Videos with David
Please share the raw videos you record in the Google Drive folder that David sets up for you. Make sure they are labeled so I know what each video is.

title: Recording
text:
Video Editing
David will edit all of your videos.

title: Overview
text:
In general, consulting projects we take on involve some combination of the following:

Data visualization
Layout using RMarkdown and pagedown
Parameterized reporting

You can see examples of several such projects on the consulting page of the R for the Rest of Us website.

title: Overview
text:
Projects We Don‚Äôt Take On
Projects that have been less successful for R for the Rest of Us are:

Ad hoc data analysis
Lack clear scope and involve ‚Äúlooking to see what data is out there‚Äù

This tweet thread has good examples of red flags to look for when considering clients/projects.


Fastest way to kill your business? Taking on the wrong clients. Here are 15 client red flags you must learn to spot:üëá

‚Äî Shane Martin (@Shane___Martin) June 8, 2022

title: Project Management
text:
Create a GitHub repo (set to private unless the client is ok with it being public):

Use the README to lay out the overall project scope, deliverables, etc.
Use issues to manage code-related questions at a granular level.
If the project is large enough, use milestones.

Create a thread in the #consulting channel on Twist for the project. This is a good place for things we‚Äôd like to keep confidential (because we work more and more with clients directly in GitHub, that isn‚Äôt the best place for confidential discussions). Communicate updates on overall progress with David using Twist. An update once a week or so is helpful.

title: Project Management
text:
Client Communication
The most important thing we can do is communicate effectively and regularly. This means getting back to clients within 24 hours.
The type of communication we use with clients depends on the client.

If clients are comfortable working in GtiHub and we decide it is appropriate to have them collaborate on GitHub, feel free to add them to the repo.
If they don‚Äôt want to work in GitHub (most don‚Äôt), email is generally best.

I generally try to send clients updates by email about overall progress every 1-2 weeks to make sure they know what‚Äôs going on and see if they have any questions.

title: Clients and Projects
text:
API Council: San Francisco-based non-profit that advocates for the Asian Pacific Islander community. We built a food resources map for them in 2021.
Aspect Evaluation: Very small (one-person, I believe) evaluation firm in Seattle. We made some visualizations for them in 2020.
Colibri Consulting: One-person evaluation firm. We partnered with them to do a report on Oregon farmworkers in 2021-2022.
CTData: Connecticut-based non-profit. We worked with them and their client the Partnership for Strong Communities to make housing reports in 2020.
Evaluation by Design: Very small (one-person, I believe) evaluation firm in the Bay Area. We helped them to develop strategy and reporting on their 21st century skills training program.

ISTE/EdSurge: A non-profit education news site. We did a couple data visualizations for them focused on COVID and school reopening in 2020.
Michigan Fitness Foundation: Non-profit focused on health. We have been doing custom training with them (mostly in the form of regular check-in calls) since 2020.
OMNI Institute: Colorado-based evaluation firm. We trained their staff on R in 2019. Since then, we‚Äôve done some additional training for them as well as some smaller consulting projects around survey reporting.
ORS Impact: Seattle-based evaluation firm. We‚Äôre currently helping them with a set of reports on 2020 Census outreach efforts.
Pacific Research and Evaluation: A Portland-based evaluation firm, we trained them in R in 2019. Since then, we‚Äôve done a few small consulting projects for them, mostly around making maps.
Prosper Portland: Small business development agency for the city of Portland. We did a training with their data team in 2019. We‚Äôve also done a series of smaller consulting projects with them since then.
Public Profit: Oakland-based evaluation firm. We trained their team in 2018.
Reading Partners: National non-profit that promotes literacy. We trained their team in 2019. We also developed an internal dashboard for them.
TORV LLC: Colorado-based consulting firm that works with golf courses and sports fields. We‚Äôre helping them to automate reporting.
The Mark: Southern California-based evaluation firm. They took some of our courses as a group in 2020 and had us develop some docs for them.

title: Finances
text:
R for the Rest of Us finances are managed using QuickBooks.
We do the following tasks in the first week of each month:
Categorize and approve all expenses in QuickBooks: If unclear on category, first look at previous months. If still unclear, ask David.
Send invoices to clients with QuickBooks: Time should be checked on Toggl reports and an invoice should be generated for each client. Some projects are billed hourly while others are billed at a flat rate (details are in the associated Todoist tasks).
Pay contractors with Gusto: All contractors will submit an invoice each month. They are then paid with Gusto.

title: Finances
text:
Quarterly Tasks
Each quarter we reconcile accounts in QuickBooks. This is done by getting statements from both Advantis Credit Union and Mercury and then entering balances here. This compares the balances in my bank accounts to those in QuickBooks to make sure everything matches up.
I also pay course instructors each quarter. You can go to the commission report on the website and see which commissions are unpaid. You can total these up for each instructor (they‚Äôre called a vendor on this part of the website) and then pay them through Gusto. Each instructor gets an advance so they only start receiving commissions when they earn more than the advance.

title: Finances
text:
Annual Tasks
We send out 1099s to all contractors by Gusto. I‚Äôve set Gusto up to make sure this happens, but we should check to confirm this in mid-January.

title: Email Automations
text:
Email marketing is the main way that R for the Rest of Us brings in revenue.
All external marketing is designed to get people onto the R for the Rest of Us email list. Once they‚Äôre on the list, we send them regular emails that educate them about R, interspersing emails that attempt to sell them on our offerings.
The specifics of how our email marketing system works comes largely from Brennan Dunn‚Äôs Mastering ConvertKit course. The process gets fairly complicated, but at the highest level, here‚Äôs what it does:
Below are details about how email automations work. Note that sequences aren‚Äôt included because they are generally just called from Visual Automations below.

title: Email Automations
text:
Signup
Here are the signup journeys that users experience on the R for the Rest of Us email list.

Getting Started
If the user gets onto the list by signing up for Getting Started, they get the tag Purchased - Getting Started applied through the WooCommerce-ConvertKit integration.
They then go through the Getting Started - Signup - Automation. This does the following:

Assigns the tag Customer - Course/Workshop
Assigns the tag Customer
Assigns the tag Flag - Calculate Next offer (which sends them through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation)
Assigns the Flag - Remove from Shadow Newsletter tag, which does what it says
Puts them through the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, which sends a set of emails about the course
When they complete the course or the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, they get pulled to the end and go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation

The Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation pitches people on Fundamentals. It happens in two ways depending on what the user has done so far on Getting Started.

If the user has the Completed - Getting Started tag, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Hot. This goes straight to the pitch for Fundamentals.
If the user has not completed Getting Started, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Cold. This sends them a few emails before pitching them on Fundamentals.

After they go through the bridge sequences, they go into the Fundamentals - Pitch - Automation.

The tag Flag - Pitch Window Open - Fundamentals gets applied. This triggers Zapier to create a personalized coupon on WooCommerce.
The user gets an email on Friday telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.
The tag Completed - Onboarding is applied.
The tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is applied. This triggers the Shadow Newsletter - Automation and adds them to the shadow newsletter.



Other Courses

If they sign up for a course, each Woo products assigns them the appropriate tag (e.g.¬†Purchased - Fundamentals).
Then, they go through a visual automation for each course (e.g.¬†Fundamentals - Signup - Automation)
Then, this automation rule assigns them the tag Flag - New Subscriber.



R in 3 Months

If they sign up for R in 3, WooCommerce assigns them the tag Purchased - R in 3 Months.
Then, they go through this visual automation, which sends them an email that welcomes them. All other communication about R in 3 Months happens directly via Gmail.



Newsletter
If someone signs up for the newsletter using this form, the following happens:

The Flag - New Subscriber tag is added to them through this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag puts them into the Global - Welcome - Sequence using this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag being added puts them onto the New Subscriber - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation and Function - Tag Custom Training/Consulting Clients - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Calculate Topics vs Core Courses

If they are a custom training/consulting client, they get the Completed - Onboarding and the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tags applied, which moves them onto the shadow newsletter
If they are not a custom training/consulting client, they are moved to the Getting Started - Pitch - Automation (if they haven‚Äôt signed up for it already)

If user signs up for you can do that, it happens with this form.
Then, this automation rule assigns them the tag Flag - New Subscriber.

title: Email Automations
text:
Shadow Newsletter
Any time the tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is added to a user, they go through the Shadow Newsletter - Automation. This does the following:

Removes the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tag (so it can be added again)
Checks if they‚Äôve completed part 1 of the shadow newsletter. If not, puts them onto that sequence. If so, moves onto the next part.
Repeats the previous step through each part of the shadow newsletter.

After the user completes each part of the shadow newsletter, they get the tag Locked - Pitched added. This puts them onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation.
New content is constantly added to the last part of the shadow newsletter sequences so that people continually receive emails.

title: Email Automations
text:
Pitching

Calculate Next Offer
Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation calculates the next offer for the user by doing the following:

Runs Function - Calculate Topics vs Core Courses to see what type of course user should be pitched on. That automation adds Flag - Pitch on Topics Courses to those for whom it is appropriate (if they have said they are intermediate/advanced, have said they‚Äôre interested in topics courses, or have been pitched on all core courses).
If user has Flag - Pitch on Topics Courses, the automation looks at which course they‚Äôve yet to have been pitched on. It then adds the next course in the following order as their next_offer custom field: Mapping, Data Cleaning, Inferential Stats.



Move to Pitch
When the user gets put onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation:

The user gets the Flag - Remove from Shadow Newsletter tag added so they don‚Äôt get newsletter emails while being pitched.
The user goes through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation, which calculates their next offer
Based on the custom field next_offer, the user is put onto a PRODUCT - Pitch - Automation for their next offer.



Self-Paced Course Pitch
All self-paced course pitches follow the same rough pattern as Fundamentals:

The user gets an email on Friday (for some courses it‚Äôs Monday) telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.

R for the Rest of Us has multiple self-paced online courses. The core courses (i.e.¬†for those just learning R) are taught by David. There are also topics courses taught by others.

Confirm instructor has access to external camera and mic
Share course-making instructions (i.e.¬†what you‚Äôre looking at)

title: Overview
text:
Don‚Äôt market, educate.

By educating, we show people what R is and what you can do with it. Once they appreciate these things, they‚Äôre more likely to want to learn R themselves or to hire us to help them do something with it.

title: Communication
text:
As a fully remote company, we try to communicate by writing as much as possible. Doing so has many benefits:

It forces us to clarify our thinking
It provides a record of decisions for those who may join things midstream
It allows people to work on their own time without feeling the need to join live calls etc

Internal communication happens, as much as possible, in Twist. There are several channels:

Consulting
Course Questions
Courses
General
Orders (all paid course orders go through here)
R in 3 Months
Training

Within each channel, we typically use one thread per project (sometimes more depending on its complexity).
Other places internal communication happens include:

GitHub for discussion of specific issues on code-based projects
Todoist comments for questions on specific tasks to be done
